Text:
To keep my records straight before I D/L,
What's the source and who did the encoding?
I try to have that info in all my files. No disrespect intended.

source is TV Land. Commercials removed using AviDemux 2 Pass 152mb, 
Data Rate 1064 kbps
Total bitrate 1192 kbps 
MP3 audio 128kbps

Not quit what I was after but close enough.
You are a gentleman and a scholar.
Thanks for sharing.
Thanks a MILLION keep it coming :-)
picture is cropped 2 much. zoom from 4:3 to 16-9.
Thanks. But 'The Scene' has gone to either Mp4 or mkv which are better quality and smaller files. Personally I prefer the Mp4, so I'll wait. It is good to know that AVI is still a choice though.

I prefer avi, and from comments when the switch happens, most people do. as avi works on stand alone dvd players.
I only have to convert MP4 to avi

cindy25, I used to feel the same way. but, the so-called scene changed the rules. the way I understand it is, if a download is created using the wrong set of rules or does not conform to the 'scene's' parameters it is nuked. and most of the new stand alone dvd players can play the mp4 format. even so with the higher quality smaller format mp4 I can put more episodes on a single dvd. I watch most programs on a PC monitor anyway. It's just a matter of preference. That being said, this has the following quality A=10, V=10.

@dukeford57, I donât think that most stand-alone players support MP4 or MKV; certainly not PS3 or Xbox 360. Sure, there may be some new and/or expensive ones that do, but for most people (like my mother), they are limited to XviD.

The main reason for the switch is because of the iPad. Unfortunately they don't realize that not everyone can afford an iPad.
